content: The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" aims to establish a framework for unilateral economic sanctions legislation to ensure effective use of sanctions in pursuit of US national interests while minimizing adverse effects on US businesses, exporters, farmers, and workers. The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" defines new unilateral economic sanctions law as any legislation enacted after the Act's date, authorizing unilateral economic sanctions by the United States. The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" defines unilateral economic sanctions as any new legislation authorizing such measures by the United States. The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" defines economic sanctions as measures taken by the United States to advance foreign policy or national security interests, constraining economic activities of individuals, entities, or countries. The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" defines economic sanctions as measures taken by the United States to advance foreign policy or national security interests, constraining economic activities, excluding obligations under international agreements. SEC. 4. GUIDELINES FOR NEW UNILATERAL ECONOMIC SANCTIONS LEGISLATION. Any new unilateral economic sanctions legislation should include a statement of the foreign policy or national security objective, provide authority for the President to refrain from imposing or suspend sanctions if in the national interest, and ensure contract sanctity unless determined otherwise. The United States legislation on unilateral economic sanctions should provide for contract sanctity unless the President determines it would hinder the effectiveness of the sanction. It should also allow the President to consider the impact of sanctions on innocent parties and not restrict humanitarian or human rights assistance. The legislation on unilateral economic sanctions should target sanctions narrowly and not restrict humanitarian assistance, agricultural exports, or activities aimed at changing the targeted conduct, unless the President deems it necessary for national interest. The legislation should impose sanctions only if it is in the national interest of the United States. The President must review the effectiveness of the sanctions annually and report to Congress. The President must review the effectiveness of sanctions annually and report to Congress, considering factors like multilateral support, costs, gains, and objectives. The President must annually review the effectiveness of sanctions, considering factors like multilateral support, costs, gains, objectives, and any determinations made to exercise authorities under the Act. SEC. 5. GUIDELINES FOR CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF NEW UNILATERAL ECONOMIC SANCTIONS LEGISLATION. In considering new unilateral economic sanctions legislation, Congress should ensure complete information on projected costs and gains to US national interests, take into account international legal obligations, and provide the President an opportunity to submit a report assessing such costs and gains. When considering new unilateral economic sanctions legislation, Congress should consider the extent to which it may conflict with international legal obligations, consistency with existing sanctions, and administrative costs. The costs and gains include the likelihood of each sanction's effectiveness. When considering new unilateral economic sanctions legislation, Congress should evaluate the cost and gains, including the likelihood of each sanction achieving its objective, importance to US national interests, and impact on humanitarian conditions. When evaluating new unilateral economic sanctions legislation, Congress should consider factors such as the likelihood of achieving objectives, impact on humanitarian conditions, national interests, relations with allies, and diplomatic efforts. This includes assessing diplomatic steps taken by the United States, the potential for multilateral adoption of similar measures, and the existence of alternative ways to achieve the same goals while minimizing retaliation against US interests. The proposed legislation may result in retaliation against US interests and harm the interests of US business, agriculture, and consumers. It could also damage the international reputation of the US as a reliable supplier of various products and services. SEC. 6. CONGRESSIONAL RULES OF PROCEDURE. The House and Senate cannot consider new unilateral economic sanctions legislation unless it includes specific matters. Any new sanctions legislation is considered a Federal private sector mandate. The Congressional Budget Office must provide a report on the mandate. The Budget Act of 1974 requires a report by the Congressional Budget Office on the costs of proposed sanctions legislation to the US economy, including impact on trade, employment, and international reputation. The section enacted by Congress focuses on maintaining the international reputation of the United States as a reliable supplier and supporting the economic well-being of US industries, firms, workers, and communities. The rules of the Representatives and the Senate are considered part of each House's rule and can override other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. RULES REGARDING SANCTIONS IMPOSED BY THE EXECUTIVE BRANCH OR BY STATUTORY ENACTMENTS. The President has the authority to suspend, terminate, or not impose sanctions if the gains for the United States national interests do not outweigh the costs. This includes refraining from imposing sanctions or suspending/terminating their application. Additionally, the President can also reimpose sanctions if necessary.
